text: disaster looms large for the country of
Japan in its history and therefore in
its art its literature and especially
its modern popular culture
but these Japanese stories of
catastrophe are rarely therapeutic or
cathartic rather their recognitions of a
basic reality that take the form of
fantasy Machir scale and quantity of
fantasy it's hard to beat Katsuhiro
Otomo z' akira a legendary anime teacher
based on his more than 2,000 page manga
akira takes place in post-apocalyptic
Neo Tokyo it's 2019 and the city is
filled with teenage motorcycle gangs
student protesters violent
revolutionaries mad scientist government
bureaucrats soldiers cops and wrinkled
lime-green children with extraordinary
powers we know the future doesn't
necessarily proceed along a single
course there ought to be a future we can
choose it's up to us to find it the
protagonist is Tetsuo a motorcycle club
who has an encounter with one of those
year children and acquires extraordinary
powers which he cannot control and which
consequently put the whole city in peril
but the point of akira is not narrative
coherence it's not to tell a neat and
tidy linear story but rather it's to
give a wide-ranging tour of the city of
Neo Tokyo
the visual effects were groundbreaking
when this movie was made and even now in
the era of 3d and digital animation and
CGI they still look fresh this is not
just a matter of technique or execution
but also and more fundamentally of
Otomo's prodigious imagination
a Karen defies genre it's a boys
adventure wrapped in a detective story
tucked inside a nuclear allegory
surrounded by a dystopian fable and
although it picks up and discards these
trappings almost at random it does so in
the service of creating a sublime and
radical new art form
but what is akhira in the film he's a
bunch of severed body parts preserved in
formaldehyde akheon he's a vulnerable
child
he's a messianic figure but above all
he's the destroyer symbol of a power
that human beings cannot yet understand
or control I am Tetsuo
you
